words.meaning: Bringing strong images, memories, or feelings to mind.
examples: The scent of cinnamon is evocative of the holiday season.
The novel is an evocative portrait of life in a small town.

words.meaning: To bring or recall (a feeling, memory, or image) to the conscious mind.
examples: The old photograph evoked memories of his childhood.
The music was intended to evoke a sense of calm and tranquility.

words.meaning: To make (a problem, bad situation, or negative feeling) worse.
examples: The new policy will only exacerbate the existing social tensions.
His angry words exacerbated the argument.

words.meaning: Past tense of exacerbate; made a problem or bad situation worse.
examples: The economic crisis was exacerbated by the political instability.
The lack of communication exacerbated the misunderstanding.

words.meaning: To demand and obtain (something, especially a payment) from someone.
examples: The kidnappers exacted a heavy ransom for the release of the hostage.
The conquerors exacted tribute from the defeated people.

words.meaning: Making great demands on one's skill, attention, or other resources.
examples: The director was very exacting and demanded perfection from his actors.
The job requires an exacting attention to detail.

words.meaning: To represent (something) as being larger, greater, better, or worse than it really is.
examples: He tends to exaggerate his accomplishments.
The media exaggerated the extent of the damage.

words.meaning: To hold (someone or something) in very high regard; think or speak very highly of.
examples: The people exalted their hero with songs and praise.
The book exalts the virtues of a simple life.

words.meaning: To irritate and frustrate (someone) intensely.
examples: His constant interruptions began to exasperate her.
The slow progress of the project exasperated the manager.

words.meaning: Intensely irritated and frustrated.
examples: She gave an exasperated sigh and rolled her eyes.
The teacher was exasperated by the students' lack of attention.

words.meaning: To remove by cutting.
examples: The surgeon will excise the tumor.
The editor decided to excise the controversial chapter from the book.

words.meaning: To criticize severely.
examples: The critic excoriated the new play, calling it a complete disaster.
The politician was excoriated for his role in the scandal.

words.meaning: Past tense of excoriate; criticized severely.
examples: The company was excoriated for its poor environmental record.
The author's latest novel was excoriated by the reviewers.

words.meaning: Intensely painful.
examples: He suffered from excruciating pain after the surgery.
The wait for the results was excruciating.

words.meaning: To show or declare that (someone) is not guilty of wrongdoing.
examples: The new evidence helped to exculpate the defendant.
He tried to exculpate himself from any blame.

words.meaning: Extremely bad or unpleasant.
examples: The food at the restaurant was execrable.
The play's acting was execrable.

words.meaning: Critical explanation or interpretation of a text, especially of scripture.
examples: The scholar wrote a detailed exegesis of the biblical passage.
Literary exegesis requires a deep understanding of the text.

words.meaning: A person or thing serving as a typical example or excellent model.
examples: She is an exemplar of courage and resilience.
The company is an exemplar of good business practices.

words.meaning: Serving as a desirable model; representing the best of its kind.
examples: He has an exemplary record of public service.
The student's exemplary behavior was praised by the teacher.

words.meaning: To be a typical example of.
examples: The building exemplifies the architectural style of the period.
Her actions exemplify the spirit of generosity.

words.meaning: Examining, including, or considering all elements or aspects; fully comprehensive.
examples: The police conducted an exhaustive investigation.
The book is an exhaustive study of the topic.

words.meaning: Making one feel very happy, animated, or elated; thrilling.
examples: The roller coaster ride was an exhilarating experience.
She found the challenge of the new job exhilarating.

words.meaning: To strongly encourage or urge (someone) to do something.
examples: The coach exhorted his team to play their best.
He exhorted the crowd to remain calm.

words.meaning: An urgent need or demand.
examples: The exigencies of the situation required immediate action.
He was prepared to deal with any exigency that might arise.

words.meaning: Pressing; demanding.
examples: The exigent circumstances required a quick decision.
He had to work long hours to meet the exigent demands of his job.

words.meaning: Relating to existence.
examples: The novel explores the existential question of the meaning of life.
The country is facing an existential threat to its survival.

words.meaning: A mass departure of people.
examples: The war caused a mass exodus of refugees from the country.
There was a summer exodus from the city to the countryside.

words.meaning: (Especially of an official body) to absolve (someone) from blame for a fault or wrongdoing.
examples: The new evidence exonerated the defendant.
The report exonerated him from any responsibility for the accident.

words.meaning: (Of a price or amount charged) unreasonably high.
examples: The hotel charged exorbitant prices for its rooms.
The cost of a ticket was exorbitant.

words.meaning: To drive out or attempt to drive out (an evil spirit) from a person or place.
examples: The priest was called to exorcise the demon from the possessed woman.
He tried to exorcise the painful memories of his past.

words.meaning: Originating in or characteristic of a distant foreign country.
examples: She loves to travel to exotic locations.
The restaurant serves exotic dishes from around the world.

words.meaning: Covering a wide area in terms of space or scope; (of a person or their manner) open, demonstrative, and communicative.
examples: The house has an expansive view of the ocean.
He was in an expansive mood and talked freely about his plans.

words.meaning: To speak or write at length or in detail.
examples: She would often expatiate on the virtues of her favorite author.
He expatiated on the topic for over an hour.

words.meaning: A person who lives outside their native country.
examples: He is an American expatriate living in Paris.
The city has a large expatriate community.

words.meaning: (Of an action) convenient and practical, although possibly improper or immoral.
examples: It was expedient to lie to avoid getting into trouble.
The government took the most expedient course of action.

words.meaning: To make (an action or process) happen sooner or be accomplished more quickly.
examples: We need to expedite the delivery of the emergency supplies.
He paid extra to expedite the shipping.

words.meaning: To officially make (someone) leave a school, organization, or country.
examples: The student was expelled from school for cheating.
The diplomat was expelled from the country for spying.

words.meaning: To spend or use up (a resource such as money, time, or energy).
examples: The company expended a great deal of money on the new project.
She expended all her energy on caring for her sick child.

words.meaning: To atone for (guilt or sin).
examples: He tried to expiate his guilt by doing good deeds.
She felt the need to expiate her sins.

words.meaning: Able to be accounted for or understood.
examples: His strange behavior was not easily explicable.
There must be an explicable reason for the phenomenon.

words.meaning: To analyze and develop (an idea or principle) in detail.
examples: The professor explicated the complex philosophical theory.
He tried to explicate his reasons for his decision.

words.meaning: Stated clearly and in detail, leaving no room for confusion or doubt.
examples: She gave him explicit instructions on how to complete the task.
The movie contains explicit language and violence.

words.meaning: To make full use of and derive benefit from (a resource); to make use of (a situation) in a way considered unfair or underhanded.
examples: The company was accused of exploiting its workers.
We need to exploit our natural resources in a sustainable way.

words.meaning: Making use of a situation or treating others unfairly in order to gain an advantage or benefit.
examples: The company was criticized for its exploitative labor practices.
The documentary exposed the exploitative nature of the industry.

words.meaning: A person who believes in and promotes the truth or benefits of an idea or theory.
examples: He was a leading exponent of free market capitalism.
She is a vocal exponent of animal rights.

words.meaning: A comprehensive description and explanation of an idea or theory; a large public exhibition of works of art or items of interest.
examples: The book is a clear and concise exposition of the author's philosophy.
The annual trade exposition attracts visitors from all over the world.

words.meaning: Intended to explain or describe something.
examples: He is known for his clear and engaging expository writing.
The documentary provided an expository account of the historical event.

words.meaning: To present and explain (a theory or idea) systematically and in detail.
examples: The professor expounded on the theory for over an hour.
He was invited to expound his views on the matter.

words.meaning: To erase or remove completely (something unwanted or unpleasant).
examples: The judge ordered the false testimony to be expunged from the record.
He tried to expunge the painful memories of his past.

words.meaning: (Especially of a document) still in existence; surviving.
examples: There are few extant copies of the first edition of the book.
The oldest extant manuscript of the poem dates from the 10th century.

words.meaning: Spoken or done without preparation.
examples: He gave an extemporaneous speech at the wedding.
The comedian was known for his extemporaneous wit.

words.meaning: Spoken or done without preparation.
examples: She delivered a brilliant extempore performance.
The debate was conducted extempore.

words.meaning: To cause to cover a larger area; make longer or wider.
examples: We plan to extend the house to create a new bedroom.
The deadline for the project has been extended.

words.meaning: Covering or affecting a large area.
examples: The storm caused extensive damage to the crops.
He has extensive knowledge of the subject.

words.meaning: The area covered by something; the degree to which something has spread.
examples: The full extent of the damage is not yet known.
To a certain extent, I agree with you.

words.meaning: (Of a factor) serving to lessen the seriousness of an offense.
examples: The judge considered the extenuating circumstances before sentencing.
He had extenuating reasons for his absence.

words.meaning: (Of a species, family, or other larger group) having no living members.
examples: The dinosaurs have been extinct for millions of years.
Many species are in danger of becoming extinct.

words.meaning: To root out and destroy completely.
examples: The government is trying to extirpate corruption.
The disease has been extirpated from the country.

words.meaning: To praise enthusiastically.
examples: The critic extolled the virtues of the new novel.
He was extolled as a hero for his bravery.

words.meaning: The practice of obtaining something, especially money, through force or threats.
examples: The gangster was arrested for extortion.
He was a victim of blackmail and extortion.
